metadata.title: Dysphonia  Unilateral V ocal Fold Paralysis in Adults
synonyms: unilateral vocal fold paralysis in adults  dysphonia
vocal fold paralysis, unilateral, in adults: dysphonia
paralysis, unilateral vocal fold, in adults: dysphonia
anatomical location body part affected: Larynx. Unilateral vocal fold paralysis (UVFP) can be caused by damage to the cranial nerve (vagus), recurrent laryngeal nerve, superior laryngeal nerve, and/or brainstem.(1) The recurrent laryngeal nerve branches from the vagus nerve at the level of the cricoid cartilage and innervates four of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx: the thyroarytenoid, the posterior cricoarytenoid, the lateral cricoarytenoid, and the interarytenoid muscles.(2) The superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory information to the larynx and also innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which causes tension and elongation of the vocal folds (resulting in a higher pitch)

presentation signs and symptoms: Dysphonia in patients with UVFP can range from mild or severe, depending on the degree of vocal fold paralysis.(3) Symptoms include breathiness, hoarseness, weakness, high pitch, diplophonia (production of two different frequencies at once), and odynophonia (pain or discomfort during voicing).(3) Dysphonia is a voice disorder marked by impaired production of the voice whereas aphonia is a complete loss of the voice Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: The assessment and treatment of dysphonia associated with UVFP are best performed by an SLP in collaboration with an otolaryngologist(3)

causes: authors of an evidence-based re: Surgical trauma (e.g., thyroid surgery, cardiothoracic surgery, esophageal surgery, head/neck surgery)(1,4)
Nonsurgical trauma(1) (e.g., head injury, cervical fracture)(5)
Tumors and thoracic diseases (e.g., lung cancer, thoracic aortic aneurysm, thoracic metastases, esophageal cancer)(28)

Systemic conditions, including infectious causes (e.g., West Nile virus, herpes, Lyme disease), neurologic disorders (e.g.,myasthenia gravis, multiple sclerosis [MS], amyotrophic lateral sclerosis [ALS]), neurovascular diseases, and malnutrition(e.g., B12 deficiency)(1,28)
Idiopathic (in the absence of a known etiology)(28)
pathogenesis: Pathogenesis varies with the cause of the UVFP
risk factors: Risk factors vary with the cause of the UVFP

overall contraindications precautions: Symptoms associated with UVFP vary widely; precautions will vary according to the individual patient and the severity of accompanying language, cognitive, sensory, and/or motor impairments
Evaluation and treatment of UVFP should be performed by a voice evaluation team that includes, at minimum, a speech-language  pathologist (SLP) and an otolaryngologist(4)

UVFP is associated with an increased incidence of aspiration in patients referred for dysphagia evaluation. Patients in whom UVFP is newly diagnosed should be assessed for swallowing function.(1) For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia associated with UVFP, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Unilateral Vocal Fold Paralysis in Adults : CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709102

Patients with recent intubation have been found to have a higher number of laryngopharyngeal abnormalities than nonintubated patients. Abnormalities include arytenoid edema, granuloma, vocal fold bowing, airway stenosis, and vocal fold paresis. The SLP should consult with an otolaryngologist if laryngopharyngeal abnormalities are suspected(6)

contraindications precautions to examina: The assessment and treatment of dysphonia associated with UVFP are best performed by an SLP in collaboration with an otolaryngologist(3)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document the cause for the UVFP and any neurological assessments, including MRI and CT scans. Document any previous surgeries, prolonged intubations, and trauma(2)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management will vary according to the patient’s presenting symptoms. Medical(7) In arytenoid adduction, the arytenoids are surgically rotated in the position of adduction and are sutured together in this position(8) injection of material into the vocal folds to allow for medialization (e.g., fat injection, Gelfoam or Teflon injection, absorbable gelatin powder, collagen)(2,7)(4,7) Medialization thyroplasty involves the insertion of a silicon implant through an opening in the thyroid cartilage that pushes against the paralyzed vocal fold, allowing it to make contact with the other vocal fold(9)Donor nerves (e.g., ansacervicalis) are redirected to supply innervation to the paralyzed vocal fold for the purpose of reducing longterm  atrophy, stabilizing cartilage positioning, and perhaps providing some tensing functions of the laryngeal musculature(8)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Is the patient taking any overthe-counter  medications?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Medical assessments will vary with the nature of the underlying condition but include

CT scans of the head, neck, and chest; examination of cranial nerve function; chest Xray;  laryngoscopy; mirror examination; strobovideolaryngoscopy; and laryngeal electromyographic (LEMG) evaluation of laryngeal muscle activity(2,4)
See Special tests specific to diagnosis  for other for diagnostic tests
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational, speech, or physical therapy. Does the patient currently receive intervention services? If so, are they school, home, or clinic/trauma center based?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Does the patient have hearing or vision difficulties (including visual neglect)? -Is the patient able to communicate orally? What modality does the patient use to communicate? What language(s) does the patient speak and/or understand? -Has dysphagia been diagnosed in the patient? Does the patient display symptoms of dysphagia? -Does the patient have accompanying language, cognitive, and/or motor deficits?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Symptoms in patients with UVFP include -loss of upper pitch range(2) -hoarseness, breathiness(2) -throat pain(2) -dysphagia(2) -frequent choking(2) -decreased vocal stamina(2) -presence of hyperfunctional compensatory vocal behaviors(e.g., excessive muscle tension of the neck)(3) -subjective dyspnea (shortness of breath)(28) -ineffective cough(30)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address presence and level of pain)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in vocal symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in voice due to weather or other external variables (e.g., distracting environment)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document any sleep disturbances caused by symptoms
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician or social worker (e.g., dysphagia, language difficulties, cognitive difficulties, mobility impairment, depression)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note any history of respiratory infection or disorders and current respiratory status for any indication of aspiration. Patients who have cervical spinal cord injuries may have to coordinate swallowing with the initiation of the expiration cycle to protect the airway(10) Note any difficulties with respiration. Disturbances in breath control and respiratory function due to airflow escape through the open vocal folds have been noted in patients with UVFP(11) Psychosocial statusThe VHI is a patient self-report inventory that contains 30 statements evaluating a patient’s judgment regarding the impact of the voice disorder on daily activities. It frequently is used as a baseline measure and a measure of the effectiveness of a specific treatment(12)A 10-item  instrument designed to measure the degree of impact that a voice disorder has on a patient’s quality of life(13,14)Document hearing ability -Does the patient have a known hearing loss? If so, does he or she wear hearing aids and/or cochlear implants? relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisA laryngeal examination must be completed by an experienced laryngologist in order to rule out the presence of any laryngeal growths, such as nodules, polyps, carcinoma, contact ulcers, and laryngeal webs. In addition, the laryngeal examination serves to determine the position of the larynx (e.g., high, low) and any other characteristics of the vocal folds, including vocal fold closure and physical aspects of the folds (e.g., swollen, tense). Patient should be referred for a follow-up  biopsy when growths are identified.(15) Laryngeal examinations may involveA mirror examination involves placing a mirror in the back of the throat of the patient. V ocal folds can be visualized by reflecting light down to the voice box(19)Rigid endoscopy is performed with a rigid tube placed into the oral or pharyngeal cavity. A rigid laryngoscope provides the clearest view of the larynx; however, the tongue needs to be held by the examiner, and normal speech production cannot be performed during the examination. A flexible laryngoscope uses fiberoptic technology and can be passed through the nose to the back of the throat and allows for examination of the larynx during voicing(20)Videostroboscopic examination allows the examiner to see the vocal folds vibrating in slow motion and provides information on any abnormalities present during voice production (e.g., abnormal closure). It is performed with instrumentation used for oral endoscopy or nasendoscopy and is combined with a strobe light correlated to vocal fold vibration.(20) The examiner can view aspects of vibratory function such as the mucosal wave, vibratory amplitude, periodicity, and symmetry.(8) Vibratory parameters usually are rated on a Likert scale (e.g., 1-5)Electroglottography is diagnostic procedure that provides information on vocal fold closure by measuring the electrical resistance of two electrodes placed around the neck(20) LEMG is an electrophysiologic evaluation of the laryngeal musculature, allowing the physician to differentiate between vocal fold immobility caused by cricoarytenoid joint pathology and immobility caused by vocal fold paralysis(31)The SLP can informally evaluate the patient’s vocal quality and breathing patterns during an interview. The SLP needs to obtain a thorough history of the voice disorder using the following questions. A family member or(3) -When was the onset of the difficulty? -Did you have prior medical or therapy consultations or treatment? -Has your voice changed over time with or without treatment? -How has your voice changed? -Have you tried any strategies to improve vocal quality? -Do you any difficulties swallowing? -Do you have any history of asthma, allergies, reflux, thyroid dysfunction, or hearing loss?
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Communication ability might be negatively affected by dysphonia. See below for specific tests for dysphonia –Assess language, articulation, and fluency as necessary(15)Identify the voice’s perceptual and acoustic characteristics (if the patient is able to phonate) and the patient’s behavior (e.g., evidence of neck strain) during voicing or voicing attempts(15)  -Acoustic measures of voice include signal-to-noise ratio, jitter (pitch perturbation), and shimmer (amplitude perturbation)(16)The patient is asked take a deep breath and sustain the vowel /a/ for as long as possible on a continuous expiration.(3) The average MPT for teenagers/adults (aged 13–65  years) without voice disorders is 25.89 seconds for males (standard deviation 7.41) and 21.34 for females (standard deviation 5.66)Number of syllables or words produced on one expiratory flowThe length of time a patient can produce “S” over the length of time the patient can produce “Z.” A number greater than 1.4 indicates difficulty with movement of the vocal folds. Normal ratio is 1During tasks such as counting and reading passages, the examiner can assess -Are the inhalations stridulous (high-pitched and noisy)? -Is air released prior to phonation? -Does the patient have shortness of breath? -Does the patient’s vocal quality change as the breath diminishes at the end of exhalation? -Is the voice weak or breathy? -Is the patient’s voicing effortful or forced? -Auditory-perceptual  evaluationA protocol and recording form to evaluate and document auditory-perceptual judgments of voice quality(17)A rating scale that examines roughness, breathiness, asthenicity (voice weakness), and strain in voice(18)Note any difficulties with positioning, tone, or postural control that interfere with communication, especially voicing. Collaborate with PT and/or OT as necessaryNote any difficulties with mobility, including hemiparesis. Examine motor function as it relates to swallowing and self-feeding.  Collaborate with the PT and/or OT as necessary
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Attention and cognitive ability will vary with the underlying cause of the UVFP and any comorbid conditions. Refer to psychological assessments as necessary

other: Refer to physician’s order for postsurgical treatment regarding specific precautions and voice rest

Therapy techniques that promote effortful vocal fold closure should be used cautiously because of the risk of developing vocal hyperfunction, which could damage the vocal folds.(21) Undesirable compensatory behaviors include anterior-posterior  or lateral compression of the false (ventricular) vocal folds, tongue backing to assist in vocal fold closure, regular use of falsetto (high-pitched)  voice, and tension of the oral and pharyngeal musculature(22)

Patients with UVFP may be at risk for aspiration. Post feeding guidelines at bedside and educate family/staff about feeding status. Discharge criteria should include patient and/or family independence with feeding strategies

Patients with diagnoses associated with UVFP (e.g., tumors, systemic conditions) may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Inform patient and family/caregivers of the potential for falls and educate about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The purpose of treatment for patients with UVFP is to improve vocal quality and eliminate any symptoms of dysphagia(2)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out The patient’s physician will rule out or identify neurologic diseases that can affect vocal fold movement, including multiple sclerosis, ALS, syringomyelia, myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barré  syndrome, and Parkinson disease(2) Central nervous system tumors and thyroid malignancies(2) Upper respiratory infection(30) Recent intubation for any surgical procedure(30)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to OT, PT, otolaryngologist, social worker, or psychologist as necessary
treatment summary: Surgical interventions: Surgical interventions may include medialization thyroplasty, arytenoid adduction, laryngeal reinnervation, and the injection of materials into the vocal fold for the purpose of bringing the paralyzed vocal fold to the midline, allowing the vocal folds to meet in the middle and close during voicing and swallowing.(24) After onset of UVFP, the waiting period for surgical interventions typically is 6 to 12 months to allow for spontaneous recovery and medialization.(25) If the patient has aspiration or an ineffective cough, early surgical treatment might be necessary(26) –Medialization thyroplasty: This procedure is the most widely used laryngeal framework surgical procedure and is a standard surgery for management of patients with permanent UVFP.(30) Researchers in Seoul, South Korea, investigated the long-term  clinical efficacy and stability of this surgery in 128 patients with unilateral vocal cord palsy and found that patients showed significant improvements in GRBAS values at 6 months postoperation. Improvements were maintained at 1 year and 5 years after operation. In addition, improvements in acoustic measurements of shimmer and jitter were evident at 6 months after the operation and were maintained to a significant extent at 5 years postoperation(29)

Speech-language  therapy for dysphonia –Authors of a systematic review that included articles published between 1980 and 2006 reported on three main types of voice therapy for dysphonia: -Hygienic voice therapy: based in the theory that functional voice disorders arise from and are maintained by harmful or traumatic patient behaviors (e.g., repeated throat clearing, dehydration) and that the elimination of these behaviors will resolve dysphonia and prevent recurrence.(35) Researchers found that the evidence to support the use of hygienic voice therapy in isolation was lacking. Review authors stated that unless scientific evidence provides evidence to support the role of hygienic voice therapy as the primary therapeutic intervention, this type of therapy should be used only as one part of a larger voice program.(35) The outcomes of the group-based hygienic voice therapy studies included in the review indicated that there were significant changes in knowledge about traumatic vocal behaviors; however, this did not necessarily equate to a change in behaviors(35) -Symptomatic voice therapy: based on the principles of symptom modification; clinicians attempt to remediate specific abnormal vocal symptoms (e.g., pitch, vocal quality, volume) with individualized, facilitative techniques (e.g., humming, yawn-sigh technique, chewing, vocal fold adduction exercises).(35) The majority of studies reviewed for symptomatic voice therapy were found to have methodological problems, resulting in doubts about the strength of the evidence. Review authors reported that the evidence was preliminary and promising, but could not be used to draw firm conclusions about the efficacy of symptomatic voice therapy.(35) Additionally, review authors noted that most studies investigated the effects of comprehensive symptomatic voice therapy programs, which makes it difficult to determine the effect of any single therapeutic technique(35) -Physiologic voice therapy: based in the theory that the best way to remediate voice disorders is to modify the underlying physiology of voice production.(35) In physiologic voice therapy, clinicians aim to 1) improve the patient’s balance of respiration, phonation, and resonance to produce voice; 2) increase the strength, health, and endurance of the patient’s laryngeal musculature; and 3) help the patient develop and maintain healthy mucosa of the true vocal folds.(35) Review authors found that the evidence for physiologic voice therapy was the strongest and was supported both clinically and theoretically(35) –Patient education about voice function and voice care -The SLP should educate the patient and/or caregiver on normal vocal fold function, the effect of UVFP, therapy techniques, and vocal hygiene. Pictures and models of the larynx are helpful in assisting patients and caregivers to understand why they cannot speak loudly and why their voice is breathy(3) –Compensatory strategies -The SLP can use the first few sessions for diagnostic therapy. Strategies to achieve a stronger voice can be trialed. Strategies include:(3) -patient applies digital pressure to one side of the thyroid cartilage (side with the paralysis) while voicing -patient turns head to one side and then the other while voicing to determine if turning to one side results in a stronger voice -amplification: The patient can use a microphone to amplify the voice if it is inaudible. In a study conducted in the United States of 18 patients with vocal fold paralysis, Parkinson disease, and/or COPD, researchers compared the use  of a fiberoptic microphone to an electret microphone. The fiberoptic microphone was found to have better acoustic performance and was associated with better patient satisfaction than the electret microphone(33) -Undesirable, hyperfunctional vocal behaviors (e.g., speaking too loudly, using too high or too low pitch) should be identified and eliminated during the first sessions –V ocal fold adduction exercises -Half-swallow  boom(3) -The steps to this technique include:(3) -the patient is instructed to take a breath and start to swallow. At the point of the half-swallow (at the peak of laryngeal elevation), the patient should say “boom”(21) -the patient produces boom in a low-pitched voice using the same technique(21) -the patient produces “boom” louder and with less breathiness(21) -the patient is instructed to turn head to each side and say “boom” each time using the same technique(21) -This technique is used to expand “boom” into words and phrases(21) -NOTE: This technique should be used sparingly and cautiously to avoid the development of vocal hyperfunction. There is little empirical evidence to support the use of this technique for UVFP(21) -Pushing exercises might be useful for patients with recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis who have a high pitch of voice production. However, for many patients, pushing/pulling/adduction exercises are contraindicated because they increase the effort needed to produce voice and can lead to compensatory patterns such as supraglottic hypofunction.(32) Steps include: -the patient is instructed to breathe in and posture on a vowel (as if about to say a vowel) without letting the air out(3) -the patient releases the vowel (vocalizes)(3) -the patient is instructed to glide down to a lower pitch as the vowel is released(3) -the patient can push hands together in front of the body or push down on the arms of a chair as the vowel is released. Another way to achieve isometric pressure is to lean into a door with elbows bent(3) -the patient can use the pushing exercise in conjunction with counting to 50 or reciting poetry(3) -The patient should maintain a constant pressure but not excessive effort(3) -the falsetto voice should be extinguished over a 3-week  period(3) -suggested frequency of this exercise is 3 times a day for the first week, 2 times day for the next 2 weeks, and then once a week. Schedule will vary depending on patient’s progress(3) -NOTE: The patient must be observed carefully for signs of supraglottic hyperfunction or excessive vocal strain. If these are present, discontinue these techniques(3) –V ocal function exercises -Steps of vocal function exercises include: -the patient is instructed to sustain the vowel /i/ for as long as possible (for pitch, use F above middle C for women and F below middle C for men)(3) -the patient should glide from the lowest pitch to the highest pitch on the word “knoll”(3) -the patient should glide from the highest pitch to the lowest pitch on the word “knoll”(3) -the patient should sustain the vowel /o/ on the notes C, D, E, F, and G for as long as possible (female patients start on middle C; males start one octave below middle C)(3) -The patient should produce vowels as gently and softly as possible without hard glottal attack(3) –Lip and tongue trills: practicing lip trills (raspberries) and tongue trills assists the patient to achieve normal laryngeal tension(3) -The patient should master the lip or tongue trill at a comfortable pitch. The lip trill can be facilitated if the patient presses cheeks in with 2 fingers -The patient can practice trills with a variety of vowel sounds and pitch progressions

In a prospective study involving 74 patients with UVFP, researchers in Italy found that early voice therapy resulted in recovery of paralyzed vocal fold motility in 51/74 patients (68.9%)(27)  –V oice therapy program included pushing exercises, vocal function exercises, and laryngeal manipulations by the SLP(27) –Frequency of therapy was twice per week with a mean number of 16.8 sessions; patients were all instructed to repeat the exercises daily at home during the treatment period(27)

Neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES): NMES is a therapeutic modality in which surface electrical stimulation is used to elicit muscle contraction through depolarization of the nerves that innervate that muscle.(34) At the time of publication, NMES is approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) only for the treatment of dysphagia; however, researchers have explored the use of NMES for treatment of dysphonia as well. Authors of a case study with two adult female patients with dysphonia related to suspected superior laryngeal nerve damage reported positive outcomes from a program of combined voice therapy (i.e., vocal exercises) and NMES.(34) For both of these patients, the NMES was applied to the cricothyroid muscle in order to stimulate the superior laryngeal nerve(34) . improved vocal pitch, quality, and funct: Patient interview regarding self-perception  of voice using formal or informal measures
improved quality of life: V oice quality of life measures (e.g., VHI,V-RQOL)

maintenance or prevention: As part of the therapy process, patients and/or caregivers should receive education on vocal hygiene (e.g., maintaining adequate hydration, reducing exposure to smoke, eliminating irritants to vocal folds such as acid reflux and pollution, reducing abusive behaviors such as excessive shouting and throat clearing)
patient education: See patient information about vocal fold paralysis from the American Speech-Language-Hearing  Association at https://www.asha.org/public/speech/disorders/V ocal-Fold-Paralysis/ Note
